content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this clash, it's not too easy  and it's not too hard, it's very good.
Thanks for that.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty decent question with an easy logic.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Quite tough for a Clash of Code question

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clash is a bit tough, but solvable in 5 minutes if you don't get stuck on the rounding issue.

This is a cool idea, but the rounding part makes it a challenge to solve in 5 minutes.

"For simplicity, every @ character shall represent 5% of all votes garnered; vote percentages for each candidate should be rounded to the nearest multiple of 5. Prefer rounding up in the case where the percentage is exactly between two multiples of 5 (e.g., round 32.5% to 35%)."

Your solution is currently incorrect on this part.
https://ato.pxeger.com/run?1=m72soLIkIz9vwYKlpSVpuhY3W9OK8nMVUlKTM3MTcxQycwvyi0oUXCBcroKizLwSDUt9EwMtQwMDTQUFZYXijPzSnBSFovzSvBSFknwFI1NVBV07BQcQgKoHy2lAzdAoLinSsFTQUjAyUNBXMDHQBAKgMemZZanFCiYwrRDHQN0EcxsA

In 'Beware rounding' it's saying that Esther and Rachel should have '@@@@' instead of '@@@@@', but they both got 9/40 votes, which is 22.5% and should round to 25% -> '@@@@@'.

Please fix your solution and the answers.
Validator 4 and 'Too many choices' are both wrong too.

This might be a bit too vague for Reverse: there are some specifics like rounding up half @'s, and sorting candidates in alphabetical order that might be missed there.
The puzzle is perfectly fine in Shortest, and okay in Fastest, but it probably shouldn't be in Reverse.
I think it takes too long to code this one (like > 5 mins).
Looks good, why not shortest?

Goal
* Point 1: Please change "corresponding" to "bar representing the".

* Point 2: Please change "and right-aligned" to ", right-aligned and padded with spaces where necessary".

Output
* Please add "bar representing the" before "percentage".

* Please change "candidates names" to "candidates' names".

* (optional) Consider removing the first two points, as they repeat requirements already stated in Goal section. Mixing repeated and new points may reduce clarity and cause confusion.

Constraints
* Please mention that all candidates' names contain English letters only.

Thanks.
Done, thank you.
Thank you for your feedback! Tbh, I'm not exactly sure why I omitted shortest mode when I first published the puzzle :)
Thank you for your feedback! I think the difficulty is suitable for clash of code but I'll leave it to the rest of the community to decide :)
Actually, yes I agree. I probably meant to omit Reverse mode instead of Shortest mode, come to think of it.
You're absolutely right, thanks for validating
Thank you for your feedback :)

No worries. The problem is that Python by default rounds half integers towards the nearest 'even' integer (to avoid having a round-up bias).

Honestly, it's a real pain to deal with half integers in a way that your language doesn't natively do it. It will make this clash a real pain for people using Python. Then if you change the tests so that the native Python rounding method works, it will be a real pain for people using Ruby (or other languages that round halves up by default)...

I think this would be a nicer clash if you could just get rid of all the situations with exact half integer results, so that the rounding is simple for all languages.

Actually, this clash was built to be a pain for Python coders (including me) xD

I just thought it would be a nice change to have the Python coders disadvantaged in a clash of code contest for once.

Probably also worth mentioning: the reason why the Decimal class approach failed was that I forgot to set the rounding approach:

decimal.getcontext().rounding = decimal.ROUND_HALF_UP
- or -
Decimal(1.5).quantize(0, decimal.ROUND_HALF_UP)

Haha, fair enough.
Setting the stage for Ruby supremacy! :P
